citeinfo.title: ESRI Data & Maps 2004 : U.S. ZIP Code Areas (Three-Digit)

descript.abstract: U.S. ZIP Code Areas (Three-Digit) represents the first three digits of a ZIP Code. The first digit of a five-digit ZIP Code divides the country into 10 large groups of states numbered from 0 in the Northeast to 9 in the far West. Within these areas, each state is divided into an average of 10 smaller geographical areas, identified by the 2nd and 3rd digits. These digits, in conjunction with the first digit, represent a sectional center facility or a mail processing facility area. These areas are serviced by the U.S. Post Office Sectional Center Facility (SCF). Note that a single SCF often services multiple three-digit areas.
descript.purpose: U.S. ZIP Code Areas (Three-Digit) provides area and population for each three-digit ZIP Code area in the United States.
descript.supplinf: Largest scale when displaying the data: 1:100,000.

The redistribution rights for this data set: Redistribution rights are granted by the data vendor for hard-copy renditions or static, electronic map images (e.g. .gif, .jpeg, etc.) that are plotted, printed, or publicly displayed with proper metadata and source/copyright attribution to the respective data vendor(s). Geodata is redistributable with a Value-Added Software Application developed by ESRI Business Partners on a royalty-free basis with proper metadata and source/copyright attribution to the respective data vendor(s).
[Applicable to ESRI Business Information Solutions attribute only]--In addition to the redistribution rights above, geodata is redistributable without a Value-Added Software Application (i.e., adding the sample data to an existing, [non]commercial data set for redistribution) with proper metadata and source/copyright attribution to the respective data vendor(s).
The terms and conditions below apply to all the data sets provided on ESRI Data & Maps.

idinfo.native: Microsoft Windows XP Version 5.1 (Build 2600) Service Pack 1; ESRI ArcCatalog 9.0.0.535

dataqual.logic: No duplicate features are present. The shapefile is converted to SDC (Smart Data Compression) format in ArcSDE. This verifies and validates the geometry.
dataqual.complete: After processing, the data set is checked for drawing display and number of records and file sizes compared with source materials.

horizpa.horizpar: The geospatial part of this data set was extracted from the 2000 Census TIGER/Line files (CD-ROM edition). To improve the accuracy, GDT ran a process against the entire nationwide database. It was generalized to 1,000 points per polygon and 4,000 points per feature. Generalizing reduced the positional accuracy and can't be determined.

citeinfo.title: 2000 Census of Population and Housing Public Law 94-171

serinfo.sername: Census of Population and Housing Public Law 94-171

procstep.procdesc:
How GDT Creates These Files: Creating ZIP Code Areas is a technical process that carefully coordinates United States Postal Service (USPS) postal data and our own Dynamap street data. The U.S. Post Office assigns ZIP Codes on a street-by-street basis. ZIP code areas are used by the USPS to deliver mail more effectively. Their purpose was never intended to form boundaries for spatial analysis. As a result, GDT formed the following processes to build boundaries from the mail stops present on street segments. By utilizing a wide variety of sources, GDT is able to locate ZIP code changes both large and small and change the representation of ZIP Code areas by redefining the boundaries.
Aligning ZIP Code Zones & Street Segments: The ZIP boundaries are created manually by following actual Dynamap street segments and other non-street features. In areas where the street name match rate is low, GDT technicians make telephone inquiries to area Post Offices, and refer to USPS ZIP+4 State Directories, to determine the predominant ZIP Code. The ZIP Code delivery "zone" is approximated, and ZIP boundaries are created manually by following Dynamap street and non-street segments.
U.S. ZIP Code Areas have been generalized to 1,000 points per polygon and 4,000 points per feature.

The following steps were performed by ESRI: Copied 2004 U.S. ZIP Code Areas and renamed it. Added ZIP3 attribute and summarized on the first 3 characters in the ZIP Code. Summarized AREA, SUMBLKPOP, and POP2003 attributes. Removed -99 values when summarizing POP2003 attribute. Manually fixed 7 features when ZIP Code is in more than one state (given to the largest area state). Corrected 000 and 001 features to be individual features for easier display. Converted the data set to SDC. Created the projection file (.prj) and spatial indices.

procstep.procdesc: This layer was originally downloaded from the ESRI Data and Maps 2004 DVD. The file was stored in SDC (Smart Data Compression) format on the DVD. ArcCatalog 9.1was utilized to export the SDC file to a shapefile and then loaded into an ArcSDE 9.1 database using the command line importing tool "SHP2SDE". Any shapes that were rejected due to bad geometry were fixed with the "Repair Geometry" tool in ArcCatalog. These shapes were then appended to the ArcSDE layer using the SDE command line tool "SHP2SDE append".

enttyp.enttypd: The polygons represent areas serviced by sectional center facilities or mail processing facilities within United States.

attr.attrdef: The 2003 estimated population of the ZIP Code area.
The three-digit number used by the postal service to identify an area serviced by a sectional center facility or mail processing facility.

codesetd.codesetn: USPS National 5-Digit ZIP and Post Office Directory

attr.attrdef: The two-letter abbreviation for the state in which the ZIP Code area is located.
The area of the ZIP Code polygon in square miles using Albers Equal Area Projection.

attrdomv.udom: Sequential unique whole numbers that are automatically generated.

attr.attrdef: The sum of the 2000 population for the Census Bureau Block polygon centroids which fall within the zip code area.
attr.attrdefs: ESRI; Department of Commerce, Census Bureau

attr.attrdef: Area of feature in square coverage units
Length of arc in coverage units
